abstract.para: Today, many people use computers with a graphical user interface (GUI) like &gnome;. Although GUIs offer many features, they are limited when performing automated task execution. Shells complement GUIs well, and this chapter gives an overview of some aspects of shells, in this case the Bash shell.

sect1.title: What is the shell?
sect1.para: Traditionally, the Linux shell is Bash (Bourne again Shell). When this chapter speaks about the shell it means Bash. There are more shells available (ash, csh, ksh, zsh, …), each employing different features and characteristics. If you need further information about other shells, search for shell in &yast;.

sect2.title: Bash configuration files
sect2.para: A shell can be invoked as an:

formalpara.title: Interactive login shell
formalpara.para: This is used when logging in to a machine, invoking Bash with the --login option or when logging in to a remote machine with SSH.

formalpara.title: Ordinary interactive shell
formalpara.para: This is normally the case when starting xterm, konsole, gnome-terminal, or similar command line interface (CLI) tools.

formalpara.title: Non-interactive shell
formalpara.para: This is invoked when invoking a shell script at the command line.

sect2.para: There are special shells that block users from logging into the system: /bin/false and /sbin/nologin. Both fail silently when the user attempts to log into the system. This was intended as a security measure for system users, though modern Linux operating systems have more effective tools for controlling system access, such as PAM and AppArmor.

The default on &productname; is to assign /bin/bash to human users, and /bin/false or /sbin/nologin to system users. The nobody user has /bin/bash for historical reasons, as it is a minimally-privileged user that used to be the default for system users. However, whatever little bit of security gained by using nobody is lost when multiple system users use it. It should be possible to change it to /sbin/nologin; the fastest way to test it is change it and see if it breaks any services or applications.
Use the following command to list which shells are assigned to all users, system and human users, in /etc/passwd. The output varies according to the services and users on your system:

sect1.title: Redirecting command events
sect1.para: Each command can use three channels, either for input or output:

formalpara.title: Standard output
formalpara.para: This is the default output channel. Whenever a command prints something, it uses the standard output channel.

formalpara.title: Standard input
formalpara.para: If a command needs input from users or other commands, it uses this channel.

formalpara.title: Standard error
formalpara.para: Commands use this channel for error reporting.

sect1.title: Working with common flow constructs
sect1.para: To control the flow of your script, a shell has while, if, for and case constructs.

sect2.title: The if control command
sect2.para: The if command is used to check expressions. For example, the following code tests whether the current user is Tux:
sect2.screen: if test $USER = "tux"; then echo "Hello Tux." else echo "You are not Tux." fi
sect2.para: The test expression can be as complex or simple as possible. The following expression checks if the file foo.txt exists:
sect2.screen: if test -e /tmp/foo.txt ; then echo "Found foo.txt" fi
sect2.para: The test expression can also be abbreviated in square brackets:

sect2.title: Creating loops with the for command
sect2.para: The for loop allows you to execute commands to a list of entries. For example, the following code prints some information about PNG files in the current directory:
sect2.screen: for i in *.png; do ls -l $i done
